prereqs: None beyond high-school algebra; designed for students with little to no experience in programming or data science.
description: Introduction to data science methods and the Python programming language for students with little to no experience in the subjects. Topics include foundational programming concepts, problem-solving strategies, and code design and data science concepts such as table operations, exploratory data analysis, and basic probability.
studentcomments: Some students report that lectures are fast-paced and may assume prior knowledge making it challenging for beginners. Several students mention the need for attending office hours and seeking additional help to grasp the material. There are concerns about the difficulty level of the course for an introductory class.

prereqs: None beyond high-school algebra; designed for students with little to no experience in programming or data science.
description: Introduction to data science methods and the Python programming language for students with little to no experience in the subjects. Topics include foundational programming concepts, problem-solving strategies, and code design and data science concepts such as table operations, exploratory data analysis, and basic probability.
studentcomments: Student feedback is mixed. One student mentions that while lectures are slow, labs can be challenging for beginners. Another student appreciates the professor's willingness to help and clear grading criteria.

prereqs: CMPSC 5A with a grade of C or better
description: This course continues the themes of CMPSC 5A. Students explore the data science lifecycle, including question formulation, data collection and cleaning, exploratory data analysis and visualization, statistical inference and prediction, and decision-making. The course focuses on transforming and analyzing data; machine learning methods including regression, classification, and clustering; principles behind data visualizations; concepts of measurement error and prediction; and techniques for scalable data processing.
studentcomments: Some students report that lectures are fast-paced and may assume prior knowledge, making it challenging for beginners. Several students mention the need for attending office hours and seeking additional help to grasp the material.

prereqs: CMPSC 8 or ENGR 3 with a grade of C or better
description: Intermediate topics in Computer Science using the Python programming language. Topics include object-oriented programming, runtime analysis, data structures, and software testing methodologies.
studentcomments: Student feedback is mixed. Some students find the labs challenging but manageable with effort, while others feel the course is overly difficult for an introductory class. Attendance and engagement in lectures are emphasized for success.

prereqs: CMPSC 8 or ENGR 3 with a grade of C or better
description: Intermediate topics in Computer Science using the Python programming language. Topics include object-oriented programming, runtime analysis, data structures, and software testing methodologies.
studentcomments: Students mention that while lectures are informative, labs can be challenging and time-consuming. Attending office hours and starting assignments early are recommended for success.

prereqs: CMPSC 8 or ENGR 3 with a grade of C or better
description: Introduction to problem-solving techniques and methodologies in computer science. Topics include algorithm development, data structures, and programming paradigms.
studentcomments: Students describe Professor Majedi as caring and accessible. Some appreciate her detailed explanations, while others find lectures slow and repetitive. Tough grading is mentioned, but assignments are generally fair and manageable.

prereqs: CMPSC 16 with a grade of C or better; and MATH 3B or 2B with a grade of C or better (may be taken concurrently)
description: Intermediate building blocks for solving problems using computers. Topics include intermediate object-oriented programming, data structures, object-oriented design, algorithms for manipulating these data structures and their run-time analyses. Data structures introduced include stacks, queues, lists, trees, and sets.
studentcomments: BURK! Man I miss this guy. Crappy lecturer; great for non-intro classes. Lectures not mandatory, interesting and advanced weekly projects, no exams. You WILL get stuck & have to wait in a long line of people looking for help, but it's worth it — I got 3x better at coding!!'

prereqs: CMPSC 24 with a grade of C or better
description: Advanced topics in object-oriented computing. Topics include encapsulation, data hiding, inheritance, polymorphism, compilation, linking and loading, memory management, and debugging; recent advances in design and development tools, practices, libraries, and operating system support.
studentcomments: Matni is a great CS professor. My third class with him and he is still great. He gives great lectures with in depth examples. The class is really straightforward and really well organized. My only gripe is that the homework is really long and hard sometimes. The exams are usually much easier than the HW and he allows an entire cheat sheet.'

prereqs: CMPSC 16 with a grade of C or better and Mathematics 4A with a grade of C or better
description: Introduction to the theoretical underpinnings of computer science. Topics include propositional and predicate logic, set theory, functions and relations, counting, mathematical induction, and recursion.
studentcomments: Lectures are confusing, disorganized, and sleep-inducing. I learned more from the 50-minute section than in 2.5 weekly hours of lecture. Get ready to teach yourself most of the content because she won't. I will say her TAs are pretty good, so definitely take advantage of that. But don't expect much from Majedi herself.'

prereqs: CMPSC 16 with a grade of C or better; and Mathematics 3C or 4A with a grade of C or better
description: Assembly language programming and advanced computer organization; Digital logic design topics including gates, combinational circuits, flip-flops, and the design and analysis of sequential circuits.
studentcomments: Professor Sherwood's lectures were great, and his lecture slides posted afterwards were even better. He connected concepts we were learning to the real world, which was interesting and inspirational.'

prereqs: Mathematics 4B with a grade of C or better; Mathematics 6A with a grade of C or better; Computer Science 24 with a grade of C or better
description: Introduction to computational science, emphasizing basic numerical algorithms and the informed use of mathematical software. Topics include matrix computation, systems of linear equations, and differential equations. Students learn and use Python libraries such as numpy, scipy, and matplotlib.
studentcomments: Professor Matni is an excellent professor. He drops the lowest quiz score, lab score, and homework grade. His lectures are easy to follow along with, and he is very funny and engaging. He clearly wants his students to succeed—his quizzes and final were all really fair and not too difficult. I wish I could have him for all my CS courses.'

prereqs: CMPSC 40 or MATH 8 with a grade of C or better; CMPSC 9 or CMPSC 24 with a grade of C or better; PSTAT 120A or ECE 139; open to computer science, computer engineering, and electrical engineering majors only.
description: Data structures and applications with proofs of correctness and analysis. Topics include hash tables, priority queues (heaps), balanced search trees, and graph traversal techniques and their applications.
studentcomments: Professor Singh has a mixed reputation. Some students appreciate his detailed lectures, while others find the workload heavy and the material challenging. Participation and asking questions during lectures help a lot.

prereqs: CMPSC 130A
description: Design and analysis of computer algorithms, including correctness proofs, recurrence relations, and design techniques such as divide and conquer, greedy strategies, and dynamic programming. Applications to various problems and an introduction to NP-completeness.
studentcomments: Professor Suri is one of the best professors in the CS department. His lecture slides are concise and to the point.'

prereqs: CMPSC 40
description: Formal languages; finite automata and regular expressions; properties of regular languages; pushdown automata and context-free grammars; properties of context-free languages; introduction to Turing machines and computability.
studentcomments: Lectures are very (too) theoretical with examples and assume you've read the book. Conceptual material taught but don't really translate into the homework entirely.'

prereqs: CMPSC 32 with a grade of C or better; CMPSC 64 with a grade of C or better
description: Introduction to the architecture of computer systems. Topics include: central processing units, memory systems, channels and controllers, peripheral devices, interrupt systems, software versus hardware tradeoffs.
studentcomments: Professor Balkind is super knowledgeable, never leaving any question unsolved at the end of class.'

prereqs: CMPSC 24 and CMPSC 32 with a grade of C or better; open to Computer Science and Computer Engineering majors only
description: Advanced application programming using a high-level, virtual-machine-based language. Topics include generic programming, exception handling, automatic memory management, and application development, management, and maintenance tools, third-party library use, version control, software testing, issue tracking, code review, and working with legacy code.
studentcomments: Phillip Conrad is great at explaining complex concepts clearly. His assignments are challenging but rewarding.'

prereqs: CMPSC 64 or ECE 154; CMPSC 130A; CMPSC 138
description: Study of the structure of compilers. Topics include: lexical analysis; syntax analysis including LL and LR parsers; type checking; run-time environments; intermediate code generation; and compiler-construction tools.
studentcomments: Clear grading criteria', 'Amazing lectures', 'Lots of homework', 'Graded by few things', 'Tests? Not many'

prereqs: CMPSC 130A
description: Introduction to the field of artificial intelligence, which seeks to understand and build intelligent computational systems. Topics include intelligent agents, problem solving and heuristic search, knowledge representation and reasoning, uncertainty and probabilistic reasoning, machine learning, reinforcement learning, and responsible AI.
studentcomments: Lots to gain from this class', 'Useful homeworks', 'Thoughtful programming assignments', 'Tests are very doable if you know the slides well'

prereqs: CMPSC 130A
description: Covers the most important techniques of machine learning (ML), including discussions of well-posed learning problems, artificial neural networks, concept learning and general-to-specific ordering, decision tree learning, genetic algorithms, Bayesian learning, analytical learning, and others.
studentcomments: Harsh grader, no curve', 'Test heavy', 'Lectures are a bit on the boring side', 'Projects are very fun and challenging', 'Grades very leniently on the projects and very strictly on the tests'

prereqs: CMPSC 130A; and, CMPSC 154 or ECE 154A (may be taken concurrently); open to computer science, computer engineering or electrical engineering majors only.
description: Basic concepts of operating systems, including the notion of a process; interprocess communication and synchronization; input-output, file systems, memory management.
studentcomments: Mixed reviews; some students find lectures organized, while others note challenges with understanding due to accent.

coursetitle: Design and Implementation Techniques of Database Systems
prereqs: CMPSC 130B
description: Queries and processing, optimizer, cost models, execution plans, rewriting rules, access methods, spatial indexing; transactions, ACID properties, concurrency control, serializability, two-phase locking, timestamping, logging, checkpointing, transaction abort and commit, crash recovery; distributed databases.
studentcomments: Mixed reviews; some students find the class straightforward, while others note that lectures can be disorganized.

prereqs: CMPSC 176A
description: General overview of wireless and mobile networking, multimedia, security, multicast, quality of service, IPv6, and web caching.
studentcomments: Mixed reviews; some students appreciate his caring nature and accessibility, while others note challenges with course organization.

prereqs: CMPSC 170 (may be taken concurrently)
description: Introduction to the basics of computer security and privacy. Analysis of technical difficulties of producing secure computer information systems that provide guaranteed controlled sharing. Examination and critique of current systems, methods, certification.
studentcomments: Great lectures; students appreciate his passion and thorough explanations.

prereqs: CMPSC 32 or equivalent
description: This course provides an introduction to digital audio through the lens of the software used by the Allosphere Research Group at UC Santa Barbara.
studentcomments: Students appreciate his passion and accessibility; lectures are engaging and informative.

prereqs: Prior programming experience
description: This course focuses on the design and implementation of one-handed spatial user interfaces (SUIs) for task assistance in AR/VR, combining theoretical insights with practical Unity projects.
studentcomments: Students appreciate her knowledge and engaging lectures; some note the reliance on group work.

prereqs: Consent of instructor.
description: The course covers all aspects of blockchains and cryptocurrencies with a focus on security, including distributed consensus, smart contracts, economics, scalability, and applications. The Ethereum ecosystem is used as a case study.
studentcomments: Great and passionate lecturer. Made the class very interesting and approachable!

prereqs: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 GPA for preceding three quarters; consent of instructor.
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
studentcomments: Professor Balkind is super knowledgeable, never leaving any question unsolved at the end of class.

prereqs: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 GPA for preceding three quarters; consent of instructor.
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
studentcomments: He made visual neuroscience very fun and interesting! Amazing lectures.

prereqs: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 GPA for preceding three quarters; consent of instructor.
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
studentcomments: Amazing professor. He puts in effort during lectures to guide all students through the material.

prereqs: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 GPA for preceding three quarters; consent of instructor.
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
studentcomments: Prof. Höllerer is a great professor who obviously cares about his students.

prereqs: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 GPA for preceding three quarters; consent of instructor.
description: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
studentcomments: Professor Sherwood's lectures are entertaining and he explains difficult material and concepts well. One of the few classes I've taken where I've actually looked forward to the lectures.

coursetitle: Ten Puzzling Problems in Computer Engineering
prereqs: Open to pre-computer engineering and computer engineering majors only.
description: Gaining familiarity with, and motivation to study, the field of computer engineering, through puzzle-like problems that represent a range of challenges facing computer engineers in their daily problem-solving efforts and at the frontiers of research.
studentcomments: Grade is based on attendance only. Really easy class, just sit in the back and sleep.

coursetitle: The Physics of Energy, Information, and Communication
prereqs: Open to Electrical Engineering majors only.
description: Introduction to the fundamentals and applications of electronic and photonic systems, covering topics such as energy, information, and communication in the context of electrical engineering.
studentcomments: Super chill professor and lectures were clear. Guest lecturers were cool as well. Tests and HW weren't bad. Thank god I could take this class instead of the dreaded CHEM 1A.

coursetitle: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits and Systems
prereqs: ECE 10A with a C- or better grade.
description: The objective of the course is to introduce the MOSFET both as a simple digital switch and as a controlled current source for analog design. The course covers basic digital design, small-signal analysis, charge storage elements, and operational amplifiers.
studentcomments: Lots of homework, but the level of difficulty was okay to me. The lecture and exams are mostly based on the textbook. As long as you read the textbook, you can get a high score for the exam. A bit strict in terms of grading, but he responded pretty quickly to email inquiries.

coursetitle: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits and Systems Lab
prereqs: ECE 10B (may be taken concurrently) with a C- or better grade.
description: The goal of 10BL is to provide the student with a hands-on application of the concepts discussed in ECE 10B. The lab utilizes the microcontroller to introduce students to the understanding of datasheets for both digital and analog circuits, single-stage amplifier design, and basic instrumentation.
studentcomments: Lots of homework, but the level of difficulty was okay to me. The lecture and exams are mostly based on the textbook. As long as you read the textbook, you can get a high score for the exam. A bit strict in terms of grading, but he responded pretty quickly to email inquiries.

coursetitle: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits and Systems
prereqs: ECE 10B with a C- or better grade.
description: The objective of the course is to introduce the student to the basics of transient analysis, including energy and power dissipation in digital circuits, first-order and second-order linear time-invariant circuits, sinusoidal steady state, impedance representation, feedback, and resonance.
studentcomments: Alizadeh is a very nice professor. He’s fair with the material and quizzes were straightforward. There was a bit of ambiguity in some lectures, but overall it was understandable.

coursetitle: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits and Systems Lab
prereqs: ECE 10C (may be taken concurrently) with a C- grade or better.
description: The goal of 10CL is to provide the student with a hands-on application of the concepts discussed in ECE 10C. The lab utilizes the microcontroller to introduce students to the understanding of energy and power dissipation, transient circuit response, sinusoidal steady-state analysis, impedance, resonance, and filter design and analysis.
studentcomments: Alizadeh is a very nice professor. She’s fair with the material and quizzes were straightforward. There was a bit of ambiguity in some lectures, but overall it was understandable.

prereqs: Either ECE 120A or ECE 124B with a minimum grade of C- or better in each of the courses.
description: Design, simulation, fabrication, and characterization of NMOS integrated circuits. Circuit design and layout is performed using commercial layout software. Circuits are fabricated using modern VLSI processing techniques. Circuit and discrete device electrical performance are analyzed.
studentcomments: N/A

prereqs: ECE 124A or ECE 123 or ECE 122A with a minimum grade of C-.
description: Practical issues in VLSI circuit design, including pad/pin limitations, clocking and interfacing standards, electrical packaging for high-speed and high-performance design. Topics cover on-chip noise and crosstalk, clock and power distribution, architectural and circuit design constraints, interconnection limits, and transmission line effects.
studentcomments: Professor Brewer is known for his structured classes and interesting lectures. He is approachable during office hours and genuinely cares about student success.

prereqs: ECE 130A with a minimum grade of C-; open to Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering majors only.
description: Analysis of discrete-time linear systems in the time and frequency domains, including Z-transforms, Discrete Fourier transforms, sampling, and aliasing.
studentcomments: N/A

prereqs: Math 4B or Math 5A recommended; open to Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering majors only.
description: Introduction to applied linear algebra: matrix arithmetic, vector spaces, orthogonality, matrix factorizations, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, difference and differential equations.
studentcomments: Professor was nice but the class was not designed very well. Lectures were too formalized and sections didn't always align with the lecture topics. Homework was given inconsistently and seemed useless since most of it never appeared again. Exams were calculation intensive and unfair since those with CAS calculators did better.

prereqs: ECE 130B with a minimum grade of C-.
description: Introduction to optical fiber communication systems, including lightwave fundamentals, fiber optics, transmitters, receivers, and system design considerations.
studentcomments: Dagli is the man! Class is difficult and a lot of work, but has many instant rewards. Dagli puts in much more time into his classes than any other professor inspires a lot of confidence in the material. You will learn a lot in this class, so much that you'll be happy with any grade he fairly assigns.

prereqs: PHYS 5 and PHYS 5L, or equivalent.
description: Introduction to quantum information, fundamentals of quantum photonics, quantum light generation and detection, quantum coherence and superposition, wave-particle duality, qubits, quantum logic, entanglement, quantum measurement.
studentcomments: Grading based on prelab and lab only. No exams at all which was a huge plus. Lectures are engaging despite how hard the concepts were. Made sure we understood it with the labs. Labs were every week in groups as well.

prereqs: ECE 10C and 10CL or 2C, and ECE 137A with a minimum grade of C- in all; open to EE majors only.
description: Analysis and design of single-stage and multistage transistor circuits at low and high frequencies. Transient response. Analysis and design of feedback circuits. Stability criteria.
studentcomments: He is a great person, I'd love to have him as a mentor or something. But his lectures were confusing and unorganized; I feel like I learned nothing. His exams are insanely hard; there is material on them that he's never gone over, but the grading is very nice. Labs are also really hard, but he offers good advice in office hours, so go to those.

prereqs: Open to Electrical Engineering, Computer Engineering, and pre-Computer Engineering majors only.
description: Fundamentals of probability, conditional probability, Bayes rule, random variables, functions of random variables, expectation and high-order moments, Markov chains, hypothesis testing.
studentcomments: Kenneth is a pretty cool dude, really just a solid person and professor. We got 1 HW assignment every week except the week before the midterm, and they're graded pretty harshly by correctness, but he drops the lowest. TAs hard carried review. The midterm and final were take home and online which saved my grade. Curved class by half a grade.

prereqs: ECE 132, ECE 134, and ECE 137A with a minimum grade of C- in all; open to EE majors only.
description: An introduction to modern switched-mode power electronics and associated devices. Covers modern converter/inverter topologies for the control and conversion of electrical power with high efficiency, with applications in power supplies, renewable energy systems, lighting, electric/hybrid vehicles, and motor drivers.
studentcomments: Professor Salem's lectures are clear and helpful, easing students into the ECE subject. Homework is challenging but intended to prepare students well for exams. Students appreciate his detailed explanations and the practical applications discussed in class.

prereqs: ECE 130A-B and ECE 146A with minimum grades of C-; open to EE majors only.
description: Optimal demodulation, including signal space geometry; communication performance characterization; advanced wireless communication techniques, including multi-antenna and multicarrier systems; other emerging frontiers in communications.
studentcomments: Students report that Professor Madhow's lectures are challenging, with a heavy reliance on his textbook. Homework assignments are lengthy and require a solid understanding of the material. Some students find his teaching style fast-paced and recommend attending TA office hours for additional support.

prereqs: ECE 147A or ME 155A with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE majors only.
description: This course involves the design and implementation of control systems, emphasizing practical laboratory experience. Students work in teams to complete a project that includes system modeling, controller design, and experimental validation.
studentcomments: Professor Hespanha is highly regarded for his well-structured lectures and comprehensive course notes. Students appreciate his approachable nature and the practical applications emphasized in the course projects.

coursetitle: Applications of Signal Analysis and Processing
prereqs: ECE 130A and 130B with a minimum grade of C- in both.
description: A sequence of engineering applications of signal analysis and processing techniques; in communications, image processing, analog and digital filter design, signal detection and parameter estimation, holography and tomography, Fourier optics, and microwave and acoustic sensing.
studentcomments: Students appreciate Professor Lee's clear explanations and engaging lectures, often highlighted by his sense of humor. However, some note that he may not be very responsive to questions during lectures or via email.

prereqs: ECE 15A and ECE 2A or ECE 10A & ECE 10AL with a minimum grade of C- in each course; or Computer Science 30 or 64 with a minimum grade of C- in each course; open to electrical engineering, computer engineering, and computer science majors only.
description: Design of synchronous digital systems: timing diagrams, propagation delay, latches and flip-flops, shift registers and counters, Mealy/Moore finite state machines, Verilog, 2-phase clocking, timing analysis, CMOS implementation, S-RAM, RAM-based designs, ASM charts, state minimization.
studentcomments: Students have noted that while Professor Li's lectures are informative, the homework assignments can be time-consuming, and exams are challenging. Some students felt that the final exam was particularly difficult to complete within the allotted time.

prereqs: ECE 152A with a minimum grade of C-.
description: Hardware description languages; field-programmable logic and ASIC design techniques. Mixed-signal techniques: A/D and D/A converter interfaces; video and audio signal acquisition, processing and generation, communication and network interfaces.
studentcomments: Students appreciate the practical approach and hands-on experience with embedded systems. Clear explanations of complex interfacing concepts.

prereqs: ECE 130A-B with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE majors only.
description: Digital Signal Processing, with Applications: The Fast Fourier transform, discrete cosine transform, and multirate digital signal processing techniques, with applications to digital cellular communications and wireless access points, and audio, voice, still image, video, and biological signal analysis, recognition and compression.
studentcomments: Professor brings extensive industry experience and provides clear explanations of complex DSP concepts. Assignments are challenging but valuable.

coursetitle: INTRODUCTION TO ROBOTICS: DYNAMICS AND CONTROL
prereqs: ECE 130A or ME 155A (may be taken concurrently).
description: Dynamic modeling and control methods for robotic systems. LaGrangian method for deriving equations of motion, introduction to the Jacobian, and modeling and control of forces and contact dynamics at a robotic end effector. Laboratories encourage a problem-solving approach to control.
studentcomments: Excellent project guidance and real-world engineering experience. Helps students develop professional skills.

prereqs: Open to EE, Computer Engineering and Computer Science with upper-division standing.
description: Introduction to multilayered neural networks, early models of perceptrons and associative memory; back-propagation learning; convolutional neural networks; recurrent neural networks; attention models; applications to natural language processing and computer vision.
studentcomments: Clear teaching style with good examples. Course material is challenging but well-structured.

prereqs: Physics 105A or Physics 103; or ME 163 or upper-division standing in ECE.
description: An introduction to nonlinear phenomena. Flows and bifurcations in one and two dimensions, chaos, fractals, strange attractors. Applications to physics, engineering, chemistry, and biology.
studentcomments: Professor explains complex quantum concepts clearly. Challenging material but good support during office hours.

prereqs: CS 130A and CS 130B or significant programming experience in large software systems.
description:
Introduction to game design, video game architectures, large-scale software design patterns,
game aesthetics, user interface design, and playtesting, all within the Unity3D framework.
Quarter culminates in a high-quality video game suitable for public release. Pre-requisite for
the advanced game-development sequence.
studentcomments: Well-organized lectures with practical security examples. Good balance of theory and implementation.

prereqs: ECE 188B with a minimum grade of C-.
description: Student groups design a significant project based on the knowledge and skills acquired in earlier coursework and integrate their technical knowledge through a practical design experience. The project is evaluated through written reports, oral presentations, and demonstrations of performance.
studentcomments: Knowledgeable instructor who provides good practical examples. Course is challenging but well-structured.

prereqs: ECE 188B with a minimum grade of C-.
description: Student groups design a significant project based on the knowledge and skills acquired in earlier coursework and integrate their technical knowledge through a practical design experience. The project is evaluated through written reports, oral presentations, and demonstrations of performance.
studentcomments: Effective teaching style with clear explanations. Good balance of theory and practical implementation.

prereqs: ECE 189B with a minimum grade of a C- or better ; senior standing in Computer Engineering, Computer Science, or EE.
description: Student groups design a significant computer-based project. The focus in this course will be on the integration of both hardware and software components. Students continue to work in groups. Apart from project reports and presentations, the evaluation will be based on successful demonstration of both hardware and software aspects of the project.
studentcomments: Clear explanations of complex architectural concepts. Assignments reinforce understanding of advanced topics.

prereqs: None.
description: General philosophy of programming and problem-solving. Students will be introduced to the programming language MATLAB. Specific areas of study will include algorithms, basic decision structures, arrays, matrices, and graphing.
studentcomments: Engaging lecturer who makes programming concepts accessible to beginners. Well-structured course with helpful examples.

prereqs: Senior standing in engineering.
description: The nature of moral value, normative judgment and moral reasoning. Theories of moral value. The engineer's role in society. Ethics in professional practice. Safety, risk, responsibility. Morality and career choice. Code of ethics. Case studies facilitate the comprehension of the concepts introduced.
studentcomments: Engages students in meaningful discussions about engineering ethics. Makes complex ethical concepts relatable.

prereqs: ECE OR CMPSC 181
description: Advanced topics in computer vision: image sequence analysis, spatio-temporal filtering, camera calibration and hand-eye coordination, robot navigation, shape representation, physically-based modeling, regularization theory, multi-sensory fusion, biological models, expert vision systems, and other topics selected from recent research papers.
studentcomments: Strong technical knowledge with clear explanations. Projects provide valuable hands-on experience.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Applications, Visual Computing and Interaction
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science applications.
studentcomments: Excellent researcher who brings cutting-edge ML concepts to the classroom. Challenging but rewarding course.

coursetitle: Advanced Topics in Natural Language Processing
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science applications. Topics are coded as follows: A. Applications, General; D. Database and Information Systems; G. Security and Cryptography; H. Computational Science and Engineering; I. Visual Computing and Interaction; K. Machine Learning and Data Mining.
studentcomments: Deep knowledge of the field with excellent research guidance. Stays current with latest developments.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Foundations, Programming Languages and Software Engineering
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science foundations.
studentcomments: Clear explanations of complex security concepts. Good balance of theory and practical applications.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Foundations, General
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science foundations.
studentcomments: Strong theoretical foundation with clear explanations. Challenging but well-structured course.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Foundations
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science foundations. Topics are coded as follows: C, Programming Languages and Software Engineering; F. Foundations, General; G. Security and Cryptography; H. Computational Science and Engineering.
studentcomments: Expert knowledge in programming languages. Research-oriented approach with good theoretical foundation.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Foundations
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science systems. Topics are coded as follows: B. Operating Systems and Distributed Systems; C, Programming Languages and Software Engineering; D. Database and Information Systems; E. Computer Architecture and Embedded Systems; G. Security and Cryptography; K. Machine Learning and Data Mining; N. Networking; S. Systems, General
studentcomments: Excellent at explaining complex systems concepts. Good balance of theory and implementation.

coursetitle: Special Topics in Computer Science, Systems, General
prereqs: None.
description: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science systems.
studentcomments: Makes complex speech processing concepts accessible. Research-oriented with practical applications.

prereqs: Computer Science 501.
description: Procedures and techniques for teaching computer science gained through actual teaching of lecture courses, leading discussion sections, and/or teaching laboratories. Meetings will be held as needed to discuss problems,methods, and procedures.
studentcomments: Provides excellent guidance for new teaching assistants. Practical teaching strategies and techniques.

prereqs: Consent of instructor.
description: Special seminars focusing on topics of interest to faculty and graduate students. These seminars provide critical review of research in various areas of computer science.
studentcomments: Good research mentor who provides valuable guidance. Helps students develop research skills.

coursetitle: Molecular Beam Epitaxy and Band Gap Engineering
prereqs: MATRL 162A-B or ECE 162A-B.
description: Fundamentals and recent research developmnets in the growth and properties of thin crystalline films of electronic and optical materials bythe process of molecular beam epitaxy. Artificially structured materials with quantized electron confinement and artificially engineered electronic band structure properties.
studentcomments: Expert in semiconductor physics. Provides comprehensive coverage of advanced topics.

prereqs: ECE 210A (may be taken concurrently).
description: Linear programming: simplex and revised simplex method, duality theory, primal-dual algorithms, Karmarkar's algorithm. Network flow problems: max-flow/min-cut theorem, Ford-Fulkerson algorithm, shortest path algorithms. Complexity and NP-completeness theory: the classes of P and NP,reductions between np-complete problems, pseudopolynomial and approximationalgorithms.
studentcomments: Excellent at explaining complex optimization concepts. Well-structured course.

prereqs: ECE 230A or ME 243A or equivalent
description: Calculus of variations and Gateaux and Frechet derivatives. Optimization in dynamic systems and Pontryagins principle. Invariant Imbedding and deterministic and stochastic Dynamic Programming. Numerical solutions of optimal control problems. Min-max problems and differential games. Extensive treatment of Linear Quadratic Problems.
studentcomments: Makes complex game theory concepts accessible. Good balance of theory and applications.

prereqs: ECE 158 or ECE 178.
description: Two-dimensional signals and systems. Two-dimension al fourier and z-transforms. Discrete fourier transform, two-dimensional digital filters. Image processing basics, image enhancement and restoration. Special image processing software available for laboratory experimentation.
studentcomments: Clear explanations of complex materials concepts. Research-oriented approach.

prereqs: ECE OR CMPSC 181.
description: Advanced topics in computer vision: image sequence analysis, spatio- temporal filtering, camera calibration and hand-eye coordination, robot navigation, shape representation, physically-based modeling, regularization theory, multi- sensory fusion, biological models, expert vision systems, and other topics selected from recent research papers.
studentcomments: Strong technical knowledge with clear explanations. Good balance of theory and implementation.

coursetitle: MACHINE LEARNING: A SIGNAL PROCESSING PERSPECTIVE
prereqs: ECE 235.
description: Machine learning algorithms from a signal processing viewpoint; unsupervised learning (K-means, deterministic annealing, EM algorithm); supervised learning (Support Vector Machines, neural networks); regression; Bayesian inference and tracking using Markov chain Monte Carlo and sequential Monte Carlo (particle filter) techniques.
studentcomments: Clear explanations of complex architectural concepts. Research-oriented approach.

coursetitle: Teaching of Electrical and Computer Engineering
prereqs: Open to Electrical and Computer Engineering Teaching Assistants only. No unit credit allowed toward advanced degree.
description: Procedures and techniques for teaching electrical engineering or computer engineering gained through actual teaching of lecture courses, leading discussion sections, and/or teaching engineering laboratories. Meetings will be held as needed to discuss problems, methods, and procedures.
studentcomments: Excellent preparation for teaching responsibilities. Provides practical teaching strategies.

prereqs: Consent of instructor and graduate standing.
description: Instruction in these variable unit courses may be carried out by lecture, by laboratory, or by a combination of these. These courses provide a study of topics of current interest in various areas of electrical and computer engineering.
studentcomments: Expert in electronic devices. Research-oriented with excellent technical depth.

prereqs: Consent of instructor and graduate standing.
description: Instruction in these variable unit courses may be carried out by lecture, by laboratory, or by a combination of these. These courses provide a study of topics of current interest in various areas of electrical and computer engineering.
studentcomments: As a graduate student who is going to focus on large data computation, this course is a very good entry point into the related field. This course not only offers the basics of tensor computation but also gives a very good picture of the current related research. But my suggestion is to have some homework as practices of simple tensor calculations.
